awd_titl_txt: CAREER: African American Father Engagement and Early Adolescents' Academic and Social Adjustment
awd_abstract_narration:
Little is known about African American fathers' parenting practices, particularly during the adolescent years. This NSF Career project examines parenting processes among a sample of African American fathers, and explores how these parenting practices influence the academic and social adjustment of African American early adolescents. Two-hundred and forty African-American fathers and their adolescents (aged 11-12 years old) will be surveyed once a year for three years. Father, adolescent, and mother reports will be utilized to gain multiple perspectives on fathers' parenting practices and adolescent adjustment. This investigation has four specific aims: 1) to investigate determinants (such as adolescent gender; intergenerational factors; residential status; maternal relationships) of African American fathers' parenting practices; 2) to examine whether fathering ideologies (e.g., beliefs about parenting) explain the association between fathering determinants and parenting practices; 3) to identify whether African American fathers' parenting practices change or are stable across adolescence; and 4) to explore how parenting practices are associated with African American adolescents' academic and social adjustment outcomes (e.g., academic performance; self-regulation; psychological functioning).

In addition to expanding the research on fathering practices in African American families, this investigation has the potential to inform future strategies to promote academic achievement and social adjustment. Also, this NSF Career Award includes multiple community-focused educational and outreach activities. First, in collaboration with the Historic Columbia Foundation, the investigator and her research team will develop a curriculum that bridges archaeology, history and psychology for use with adolescents. An additional component of this curriculum will include a joint father-adolescent learning activity. Also, educational outreach materials (e.g., flyers; workshops) will be developed for local school districts and educators regarding the importance of father involvement during adolescence. Last, in efforts to increase exposure to science research and associated careers, this project will provide intensive mentoring and training opportunities for underrepresented high school, undergraduate, and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Fewer studies have examined African American fathers' contribution to normative developmental processes during adolescence. Further, less attention has been given to within group variation among a socially and demographic diverse sample of African American. Addressing these gaps, this CAREER project had 2 primary aims: 1) assess factors and processes that shape parenting and involvement among African American fathers and 2) explore how fathering practices were associated with the psychological and school adjustment of African American adolescents. 

Across the entirety of the project, there were several scientific contributions. This project examined how parenting factors (e.g., adolescent gender; residential status; intergenerational experiences; parenting self-efficacy; discrimination experiences) shape African American fathers' involvement. Extending prior studies, this investigation emphasized the role of intergenerational factors (e.g., childhood and current relationship with father), including both direct and observed experiences. Further, findings from this study identified mechanisms that may provide additional insight into this relation. For instance, the project demonstrated that intergenerational factors may influence involvement via an impact on parenting and fathering specific ideologies.

 Though much discussion has centered on the racial experiences of African American men, very little research has examined these experiences within a parenting context. This project greatly extends this literature by examining the association between fathers' racial discrimination experiences and their parenting ideologies and practices. This project demonstrated that discrimination experiences shape fathers' discussions about race and culture with their adolescents. These discussions have been found to contribute to positive developmental outcomes among ethnic minority adolescents. Further, this investigation demonstrated that these discussions are an interplay between father (racial discrimination experiences) and child factors (e.g., gender). Another intellectual merit of this project was examining the joint influence of generally and culturally specific parenting practices and behaviors as well as how they are related to adolescent adjustment. 

Additionally, this project had several broader impacts. Findings from the project have the potential to inform prevention and intervention as well as policy related to father involvement and engagement. Also, a number of studies have suggested that fathers, particularly minority fathers, may be less likely to participate in developmental research. This decreased participation is, in part, a response to greater mistrust due to persistently negative portrayals, depictions, and stereotypes about minority fathers. This project highlighted the utility of community-based recruitment strategies for engaging minority fathers in developmental science research, emphasizing the impact of engaged and responsive strategies for recruitment and retention fathers in family-focused, longitudinal studies. 

Also, this investigation increased underrepresented early career scholars' (undergraduate; graduate; post-baccalaureate) exposure to research through the provision of high-quality, in-depth research training and professional development. Several students have directly benefited from the project, including participating in lab research activities as well as contributing to lab publications and scientific presentations. These activities have contributed to students' professional trajectories (e.g., admission to highly ranked doctoral programs; postdoctoral fellowships; tenure-track faculty positions), ultimately increasing the pipeline of minority scholars into research and STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2019
Modified by: Shauna Cooper
